et: Middle English {it}round, rounde{/it} "spherical, circular, rounded," borrowed from Anglo-French {it}reund, rund, rount,{/it} going back to Vulgar Latin {it}*retundus,{/it} altered (by presumed vowel dissimilation) from Latin {it}rotundus{/it} {ma}{mat|rotund|}{/ma}

cylindrical
approximately round

et: Middle English, "in a circle," derivative of {it}round, rounde{/it} {et_link|round:1|round:1}
shortdef: around

dt: {bc}something (such as a circle, globe, or ring) that is round
{bc}a musical canon in which each part begins on the same note and is continuously repeated
{bc}a rung of a ladder or a chair
{bc}a circling or circuitous path or course
{bc}motion in a circle or a curving path
{bc}a route or circuit habitually covered (as by a security guard or police officer)
{bc}a series of similar or customary calls or stops

dt.t: They were always together, fighting to cure paralysis. An endless {wi}round{/wi} of fundraisers, Congressional testimony.
You see, in election time local politicians, aspirants for office, have a way of making the {wi}rounds{/wi} of the saloons to get votes.
… no one … was surprised to see him making the TV news {wi}rounds{/wi} within hours of his announced termination …

dt: {bc}a series of regularly scheduled professional calls on hospital patients made by a doctor or nurse

dt.t: … if laboratory test results are not available to physicians when they make their routine morning {wi}rounds{/wi}, they may have to delay patient management, repeat their {wi}rounds{/wi} at a later time, and perhaps prolong their patients' hospital stays.

aq.auth: David A. Novis and Jane C. Dale

dt: {bc}a drink of liquor apiece served at one time to each person in a group

{bc}a unit of action in a contest or game which comprises a stated period, covers a prescribed distance, includes a specified number of plays, or gives each player one turn
{bc}a division of a tournament in which each contestant plays an opponent

{bc}in full sculptured form unattached to a background
{bc}with an inclusive or comprehensive view or representation
{bc}with a center stage surrounded by an audience

et: Middle English {it}rond, round, rounde{/it} "spherical body or form, circle," in part derivative of {it}round, rounde{/it} {et_link|round:1|round:1}, in part borrowed from Anglo-French {it}rund, rond{/it} (in {it}en rund{/it} "round about") and {it}runde{/it} (in {it}a la runde{/it} "round about"), both nominal derivatives of {it}reund, rund{/it} {et_link|round:1|round:1}
shortdef: something (such as a circle, globe, or ring) that is round
a knot of people
a circle of things
